message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, notably the high calcium level and elevated PTH, suggest hypercalcemia. Among the options, only Vitamin D toxicity can cause hypercalcemia. Primary hyperparathyroidism is a possible cause but the elevated PTH level indicates that it is secondary to another condition. Primary hypothyroidism and excess calcium intake are not likely to cause hypercalcemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest hypercalcemia, and the calcium level of 12.8 mg/dL confirms this. One of the common causes of hypercalcemia is vitamin D toxicity, which can occur with excessive supplementation or overproduction by the body. Primary hyperparathyroidism can also cause hypercalcemia, but the normal PTH level makes this less likely. Primary hypothyroidism can cause constipation and decreased appetite, but it is not usually associated with hypercalcemia. Excess calcium carbonate intake is also unlikely as the patient's diet was not mentioned to be high in calcium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including constipation, decreased appetite, and high calcium level, all suggest hypercalcemia. Among the options, only Vitamin D toxicity can cause hypercalcemia. The patient’s history of taking over-the-counter supplements and recent increase in exercise may have contributed to the toxicity. It is also worth noting that Primary hyperparathyroidism is another potential cause of hypercalcemia, but the patient’s high PTH level suggests secondary hyperparathyroidism due to the Vitamin D toxicity.
